question: How long is Earth's orbital period around the Sun?

content.source_2: Earth is a planet in the Solar System that orbits the Sun at a mean distance of about 1 astronomical unit (AU).
content.source_3: For bodies orbiting the Sun, Kepler’s third law (P^2 ≈ a^3, with P in years and a in AU) implies that an object at 1 AU has an orbital period of about 1 year.
content.source_4: One year corresponds to about 365 days (approximately 365.25 days when accounting for leap years).
content.source_5: In the historical Ptolemaic (geocentric) model, Earth is stationary at the center and the Sun circles Earth roughly once per day; in that framework Earth does not orbit the Sun.
content.source_6: If an object does not orbit another object, its orbital period around that other object is undefined because no orbit is completed to time.
